title: Bearing belt guard for reprappro mendel

description.text:
The original belt guides for the Y belt kept breaking for me so I made this quick n dirty, but sturdier version. Just loosen the nut, push the guard on the M8 and tighten the nut again. It became a bit too large but works fine.  
Half a broken original guard can be seen in the photo. Note: the photo only has one of the guards in place, the other is in the printer.

author: pinussen

description.text: For mounting a stepper motor in OpenBeam applications http://blog.openbeamusa.com/2012/05/29/in-depth-nema-17-mount/

If you modified your Simple using Jon Lawrence's excellent Belt Drive X-axis Upgrade (if you flipped your bed mounting plate so the tabs are now forward) then you lost about a half inch of available printing space in the Y axis.  This Extruder Plate adds 15 mm to the Y axis and your prints should be just about centered.  I have added it to a 2013 SImple with XL upgrade (aluminum exturder) and a 2014 Simple.  Works fine on both.

comments.author: mx5

comments.text: You have not shared anything useful... This is just an advert for your paid for plans. Bad form dude. Not in the spirit of the site! Shame on you.
comments.author: Justblair

comments.text:
Hello Justblair,
1) The Spirit of this site:
This Site is operated by MakerBot. It's a great "idea" an it is a great "marketing idea". They sell very nice 3d printers and their printers will love to print my "Reprap-Windturbine". Thanks to Makerbot for this site!
2) I have not shared anything useful?
This is what you think. I had a look at your "Things". There is this little "plastic-yoda". You think a little "plastic-Yoda" is more useful than a well designed windturbine that generates electricity without atomic risk and airpolution. I think different.
I think it is time that we use our printers not only to extrude plastic in little yodas but to use it for good things on earth, too. Such projects sometimes are a lot of work. I spend two years and a lot of money in it. I will never get the money out, but if I get a little money back it helps me to go on with the development of "good" and well designed projects.
I give it into the hands of the makerbot-team to delete my account and I will accept their decision.......and the makerbots will still love printing my "Reprap-Windturbine", because it's a good thing on earth...and it's fun!
Best Regards
Andy4print

title: OpenBeam 608 bearing to NEMA 17 mount adapter

description.text: Our 608 Bearing to NEMA17 adapter is essentially a standard 608 skate bearing pillow block with a NEMA17 motor mount pattern. This allows the other end of a long drive shaft to be supported using the same bracket work that is supporting the NEMA17 motor. http://blog.openbeamusa.com/2012/05/29/in-depth-608-bearing-adapter/
Each of the mounting bolt holes contains a captive hex nut geometry. You can use this to capture either a DIN934 compliant nut, a nylock nut, or the head of a hex head cap screw.

title: Shell approximation of solid of revolution I
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The model pictured on the left is the solid obtained by revolving the region between the graph of y=4-x^2 and the x-axis on [0,2] around the y-axis, and the model on the right is an approximation of that solid using eight shells. For more information about the math behind approximating volumes with shells, see the link below. MakerHome, Day 237:
http://makerhome.blogspot.com/2014/04/day-237-shellmaker.html UPDATE: Now with a handy base to match the Taalman/Kohn calculus book! MakerHome, Day 243:
http://makerhome.blogspot.com/2014/04/day-243-base-for-shell-models.html =====

Created for CTC Replicator clone to use as replacement for the filament bowden tube. In the meantime replaced by a better version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:631223 This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/cOJXqZxP76n

Suggested printing ...
  • PLA (more elastic)
  • 40% infill
  • 0.3mm layer
  • pre-guide with support
    • You can print the pre-guide upright without support, but only if you have an additional hot-end cooling fan. Otherwise the upright part will be very ugly due to printing hot on hot.

title: 60mm Fan Adapters - Deprecated
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are now deprecated and replaced by version 2 - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:469923
This converts a different sized fan (25mm thick) for use on a 60mm x 10mm fan connector. By doing this your noise level and sound level can be EXTREMELY decreased while putting out more CFM than a 60mm can do.
There are extra tall versions (30mm taller) that allow more airflow to pass.

This requires 4.5mm x 15mm fan mount screws for the 60mm side and 4.5mm x 30mm for the 120mm fan connection (4 of each type) and 4mm x 30mm for the other sizes. All mounting fans need to be 25mm or adjust the length of the 4 screws it uses. Use heavy infill for this since it will need it and I honestly suggest 75% to 100% due to the weight of the larger fans and the screws need the infill to really dig into.
The file is uploaded to show how it will look when mounted so flip it however you think will print the best for you and your machine but I think 180 degrees around (60mm side up the larger side down) should print better.

remixed_from.author: Wired1
remixed_from.title: X-carriage with fore & aft fan mounts

description.text:
Yes more is better - when it comes to bearing holders anyway.
Tired of snapping those pesky bearing holders when you tighten the screw one turn too many? well I know I am so this design uses four individual bearing holders keyed into position on a rigid x-carriage platform.
No laminar separation or splitting issues here.
Also features twin fan mounts fore and aft for my fan holders and VGA fans like here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29158
The four other holes in the top of the platform are for 5mm LEDs -connect 4 blue or red ones in series directly across 12 volts - like your fan supply for example.
  • you don't really expect this to be unbreakable do you?
    • 19 September - Added fixed belt grips to give clearance from the 8mm x-axis rods.

Print out the parts, you will need one x-carriage platform plus 4 bearing holders from here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30365
Run a 3mm drill through all the machine screw holes after printing and use a 7mm drill bit by hand to clear the screw head recesses on the top side (the extruder needs to pass ofer these).
You will need to carefully cut eight 3mm machine screws to hold the bearing holders into their recesses so that they do not protrude past the captive nuts - this is where the LM8UU bearings will sit.
Place the assembled carriage on the x-rails or runn the two rails through the LM8UU's and then tighten up all the bearing holder screws - this will ensure it is correctly aligned.
I have used the usual belt clamp/tightener arrangemenr and will upload a photos of it when I finish building this printer. You also need the fixed belt grips that miss the x-axis rods (or trim the ones you have with a sharp blade).

comments.text: Where can I find the required fixed belt grips? Thanks!
comments.author: davidbitton

comments.text: Built this and it's working quite well, more stable and lower friction(dunno how!) than the stock i2 X-carriage, but there is one improvement I'd suggest, if you make the bearing clamps 1.75mm thicker then it will work with standard M3x8mm pan-head screws instead of needing to grind screws to a precise length for it. I printed and added little spacer blocks to make that work.

author: doctormao

description.text:
Dishwasher around here are offered under various brands, but they are all pretty much the same unit. 
The wire basket that holds the dishes has wheels that clip on to the basket.  These wear out sooner than most of the rest of the unit.  
These clips replace the original wheel bearing clips with a tighter tolerance.
PLA prints have held up well after several weeks, with no sign of failure.

Measure the wire on the basket where the wheel clip on.
Adjust the SCAD file.
Print with support.  The part will need filing.  
Clip on wheel, then clip to basket.  Notice the wheels no longer fall from the track.

title: Cube lead screw XY hotend carriage

description.text:
New video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OhLpAUZf8RU
A little video is better than word http://youtu.be/oA6E8RVCTIo
I change a little the STL of XY hotend Carriage to add support for endstop and also to include nuts.
I made this to go with high speed lead screw from Igus. It is a 10mm with a pitch of 50mm with 10 starts. The lead screw with two nuts is around 300$...
I use two bearings 19/10/5 on each X and Y carriage to the opposite of motors for the lead screw.
8 mm stud with LM8UU bearing for guide.
To carry the hotend carriage I use 10mm stud w/LM10UU
It is suppose to work Bowden 3MM extruder and the design is done for a E3D regular hotend.not the bowden one.
The E3D is clipped .
A new video with some improvment concerning the X/Y motor bracket https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dkuh3Aqka00

car mount cradle and dock for HTC rezound

This has been printed and i'm using it in my car at the moment, The little cylinder thing on the primary and secondary arms is for a 2" piece of ~18 gauge steel wire to fit through and provide some flexibility/hold to the assembly. To hook the disk and the disk lid and the cradle all together, sit the lid in the cradle, then put the lid on top of it, take a soldering iron, and run it around the edge between the lid and the back of the cradle, melt the plastic together between the two and vuala! plastic welding. To actually mount it to a windshield you will need any old mounting kit suction cup assembly. (or just print some adapter from this to a random suction cup from something else)
My old one was just a suction cup and a lever with a bolt through it, (hence the weird back end of the primary arm) it fits a 5/16" hex cap screw (or there abouts, the space is enough to fit .35" or 8mm hex cap nut.) You should be able to squeeze in a M3x16mm bolt and nut on there and should have a snug fit, if you cant fit it file it out a tiny bit and thread it on in there. (makes for less random falling apart and more holding position) I added another bit of wire around the bolt head in the secondary arm to support the x axis rotation stay in one place. It works for me, so I haven't had the energy to modify it to make a more permanent solution to support that joint in particular. Let me know if you would like the permanent mods, i'll work on them.

I have Ultra narrow kitchen drawers and I needed to organize my utensils, and no store bought thing would fit these damned drawers, so... I printed one. (in 4 pieces) My drawrs are exactly 8" wide, so if your's are smaller, might wana make one of your own. also, they fit my utensils (which are a normal size/large I suppose) so no guarantees on it fitting all your forks knives and spoons!

If you have a big printer, print it as 1 piece (lucky b#&@*&$'s) if not, I printed mine in 4 pieces at 90degrees from flat to get all the features and not run in to the damn bolts that hold the HBP on.

title: Sliding Rail Mount System for a spice rack

description.text:
I made these raised slide rails for a vertically mounted slide-out spice rack. The rack came with short rails that didn't fit my kitchen cabinets. I could have just made spacers, but decided to redesign the whole slide rail mounting system.  
I include the scad so you can customize it any way you want. The important bits are adjustable such as length, base height, rail height, gap, etc.

I included two rails at a time, side-by-side in the stl to avoid ABS lifting/warping. If you want a different configuration, scroll to the bottom of the scad. Each rail is wrapped up in the module called "final".  
I printed 3 sets for a total of two 10" long rails. (top and bottom mounts)  
The overhang for the rail capture is only at 15 degrees. It prints fine for me because it's only a few lines, but if your printer isn't up to it. You might want to increase the angle to 45.

adapter that lets you replace the tiny bubble juice bottle a bubble gun with something a little bigger (a small water bottle)

This thing has very thin walls, lots of overhang and is generally a pain in the butt to print. I had good success with PLA, 0.35mm nozzle, 185C, 0.1mm layer height, printing on blue tape. Printing on heated glass did not work well as the warm glass prevented it from cooling quick enough. If you don't have a really good cooling fan, it might be helpful to print more than one (or print something else at the same time) to let the layers cool.
As a bonus, the scad file is parametric and could probably be used for making other kinds of thread adapters.
Vases

title: Wooden Spool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Printing out spools is expensive. Cutting them out of MDF is cheap.

The spools are 160mm in diameter and 90mm in width. Each spool requires two ends and two plates cut out of 3mm MDF and glued together.
The easiest way is to print out the PDFs, double-check the scaling is 1:1, glue onto the MDF and cut out using a scroll saw. I suppose laser cutting can also be used.
Drill some 2.5mm holds in one plate to attach the start and end of the filament (see the picture).
Each spool easily holds 100m of 1.75mm PLA.
No DXFs are available as the DXF export from Alibre Design seems to have problems.

author: ajayre

title: Print wood now - with tree rings!  LAYWOO-D3 mm filament

description.text: Print your design with a new 3 mm wood-filament.

Printable wood / LAYWOO-D3 / is a new FDM filament that I developed within the last year as an alternative printing material.
It allows to print wooden-like objects with annual rings - and that without warp ! The original design for my first reasonable print is a concept toy -
"locomotive with plugable wheels" from the 80-ies (designed by Grit Weiss Annaberg) that I rebuilt with permission for 3D-Printing.
Using the main parts as boiler boiler-plate wheels smoke pipe there are easy modifications possible to create waggons for a complete train.
You can print the filament in a range from 175Â°C to 250Â°C without blockage the nozzle.
The flow of molten LAYWOOD3 is excellent.
The printed wood will appear rough, similar to MDF Medium-Density Fiberboard
Playing a little with material feed settings brings more craters or smoother surface. Annual-Rings printing-temperature:
180Â°C = bright colour,
245Â°C = dark wooden effects features of LAYWOO-D3 near zero warp rough or smooth surface possible during one print paintable, grindable, cutable with saw printable tree-rings stics well on print bed, no heated bed necessary the filament contains recycled wood and harmless binding polymers the material has similar thermal durability as PLA is not dedicated to substitute the "good old wood or bamboo" Hygenic aspects: The composite material contains recycled wood and only such polymers that are harmless, but printed parts should not be eaten.
To be honest - because the filament contains the half polymer binder - itÂ´s not a typical bio-product and sadly not cheaper than standard ABS or PLA.

your requests:
I sell little trial amounts (0.25Kg)
german ebay: search: printable wood / LAYWOO-D3 / trial amount

I needed an insulated Arduino Bumper for a project at work. The bottom had to be covered to protect against shorting.
In addition to a covered bottom, I added a ridge at the top of the lip to hold the Arduino in and give you that satisfying "click" sound when you fully insert the Arduino. I also thickened the lip to make it a little more durable and lengthened the board a hair to compensate more for rough board edges. Finally, I enlarged the mounting holes slightly to make them clearance holes.
UPDATE 9/17/2012: I rebuilt the CAD drawing to clean it up and added some fillets for improved lip strength. Download the second file for this new and improved version.
This was derived from the Arduino Bumper by Chu.
UPDATE 7/3/2014 I redesigned this to eliminate the unnecessary plastic from the interior. Also, 3 simple cuts around the USB and power can modify this to work with the Arduino Ethernet.
Print, let bed cool down, carefully remove.  Insert Arduino, ICSP connector end first.  Carefully insert till you hear the click sound of the retaining lip grabbing hold.

This is a holder designed for bicycle bags that mount the baggage porter on the bike (like those from Ortlieb). At home those bags usually lie around somewhere and are a bit of a pain to pack when not mounted to a bike. This thing gives you a wall mounted baggage porter for your bags!

• print n brackets where n is one more than the number of bags you'd like to hang. (For 2 bags, print 3 brackets.
  • find a position on the wall where you'd like to mount the bag holder
  • mark the positions for the bore holes (in Germany we mostly have brick walls, so we need to bore a hole before mounting anything to a wall...)
  • bore mounting holes in the wall
  • mount the individual brackets without the rod.
  • cut rod/tubing to length
  • carefully push the rod through
  • hang bags
    • I printed the brackets with a .5mm nozzle from ABS with a layer height of .2mm. The print came out ok. The overhang doesn't look too good, but it's fine for the intended use.
    The bracket might look flimsy but worked for me so far: I'm sometimes putting 5kg upwards in a single bag. Only mount the brackets with the rod/tubing on the upper side, otherwise they will break much easier. BoM (for 2 bags):
  • n x printed brackets (n=3)
  • 2*n x screws for mounting the brackets (6)
  • 1x 8mm rod (I used some 8mm aluminum tubing from the hardware store)
    • BTW: http://www.ortlieb.de/ bags are great!

author: jjk

description.text:
My parents' Renault Clio broke. Well, not whole car, but driver's seat regulation lever.
So I have modelled the new handle in less than hour. It is very strong and fits perfectly. It looks like new now! (well, it IS new)

Print the handle with not less than 0.5 fill, 0.3-0.4 mm layer, perimeters of three; element is big enough to print it full-speed of your printer. Clean-up by cutting away supply material (is is made to remove with screwdriver and knife, not very sharp to cut between layers.
Hit it with the hammer on to the square-rod and voilla! Enjoy your NEW seat lever!
The handle has small (0.5mm) rod-guides inside to keep it in place tightly.

This is a shroud designed for a Pinnacle Pro Vaporizer made by The Vaporblunt company.  
It's function is to stop the mouthpiece and particularly when using the water tool attachment from falling off while in use.  
It has been designed to fit snugly so you will need to print it with an infill of 10-15% to allow the sides to bend out slightly.  Any more and it becomes to difficult to remove.  
Fell free to remix it as I am only just learning sketchup.  I intend to make a more streamlined version but this one is functional so I have released it while I'm working onit.
Make sure you print with 40% infill otherwise the sides won't bend properly.

This is a replacement foot for a generic step stool with 5/8" OD steel tube legs.  Helps keep the legs from marring wood floors.  The bottom of the foot is domed just like the original.  
Why throw out the step stool just because it lost its feet?  Or why bother going to the hardware store looking for replacements only to find they're sold out (as happened to me).  This part is easy to print and needs no support.  
Openscad source is included for your modding pleasure.  Just change the variable "OD" for different size tubing.

Ideally you want to print this with a flexible PLA filament so that it will provide the same cushioning as the original rubber part. I used the following settings on my Printbot+: Extruder: 205 deg.
Bed: 85 deg. with ABS-juice coated blue tape
0.5 mm. extruder nozzle
33% infill
0.3 mm. layer height
Cooling on constant after 1st 1.0 mm.
Print SLOWLY! Mine takes about 15 minutes per copy. When done, just push the foot into the tubing and hey presto, good as new. And a big shout-out to LucidOne for his excellent and elegant curve forming code here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6455/#files. That made my job a lot easier.

title: Extruder plate for wallace and makergear hot-end or j-head

description.text: A plate to put on the X-carriage of the wallace and under the extruder to have possibility to put a makergear hotend with 36mm barrel, or a jhead. Because The X-carriage is too high to put this without that. It also have a 40mm fan mount to keep carriage and extuder cool.
Print, remove the little supports, put under (inside) the extruder (extruder have to be printed with jhead parameter). Put your hotend in it, screw everything, add a 40mm fan, screw it, enjoy.

description.text:
This stop let me print on all my bed, even if I have only one wooden plank.
The fact of having only one plank makes it hart to have the endstop switch on the same rod as the bed. This part enable me to reverse the orientation of the endstop and access the full bed.

Just print that part and fix it under the printing bed, just under the belt clamp.
This part was designed under solidworks, the butee.SLDPRT file is the description of the part itself, the assemblage.SLDASM file just rotate the part so that it is easy to print.
If you just want to print this part, use the assemblage.stl file.

A modular rack system for the Raspberry Pi.
I made it so the audio/composite ports basically hold the Pi in place.
(If making a cluster, I'd think audio and even video wouldn't be needed. I'm ssh'ing into the Pis) The top support is for 5 Pis (easy enough to change/redesign fro the # you need) As a footnote, the Pis are a little crooked; I didn't feel like fixing it, needed the system up and running. There seems to be a slight difference between the Element 14 and the RS versions on the audio connector. The Element 14 seems to a little shorter and spaced a little further apart, both by abut .5mm
Dovetails might need a little filing for a good fit.

comments.text: This is great. Thanks for the design. I'm putting some old Pis to work (pi-hole, musicbox, etc) and they're getting pretty hot, so I'm going to design a fan box and put this inside.

hi
could you please consider revising this design for the Raspberry Pi B+ model?
the key difference would be using the hdmi port instead of the now missing video port, but this should

hdmi cable glued in, this will make the mount very secure and flush. please consider!
thanks
brad

UPDATE 19th JUNE  Unlikely to be updating this thing in the future, do the work I've been doing on my new 3D Printer, which will be able to print with 4 extruders, print much faster and build things at 300x200x315mm. Will upload this to thingiverse fairly soon. Thanks, Sam.  
Update 27th April 2013 - Printer's working well - will add more photos soon. Along with updating the rest of this page.  
This is a 3D printer I'm designing and building.  
Frame - Aluminium Extrusion from 8020.net its a 1.5" wide profile drilled with holes for M8 or imperial bolts. They connect with aluminium inserts and general hardware, washers and nylock nuts etc. For my first Frame I'm actually using an etch spray primer and satin black paint.  
Linear motion - X and Y are Pulley driven with Z being high quality stainless threaded bar. All 3 axis are guided by LM10UU bearings and 10mm stainless rod.  
I also hope to add an LCD display and possibly a tablet pc/ipad mount on top for the interface.

comments.text: Did you ever complete it?
comments.author: rjwilson18

comments.text: Any update about progress of your project?
comments.author: maxoutny

comments.text: The machine's printing, but I've had problems the last couple of days with my computer randomly logging out during a print - so my 12h print of 6 large components at the same time stopped after 2 1/2 hours for example. Thinking that I may switch to printing from SD until this problem is fixed
comments.author: maxoutny

comments.text: Try to change power saving on you computer setting to never stand by (all ways on).
comments.author: Saminvent

comments.text: it was already set like that, but for some reason still went off... I did an update (EFI update  - I'm on mac) but have been swapping over to repetier so don't know whether it fixed it
comments.author: maxoutny

comments.text: Hi Sam, Great looking design. I'd be interested to see a parts list if you have something available? You are probaby aware that one of the biggest issues can be the stability of the Z axis as threaded rods may not be entirely straight. I think that your design would prevent distortion in the Y axis, but think that wobble caused by the Z threaded rod may be seen in the X axis (possibly).
comments.author: MarkPate

comments.text: Hi Mark, The z axis threaded rods are only mounted by bearings at the top, on the bottom they are free to move around as they like, I haven't really noticed any problems with wobble so far thankfully, really busy at the moment, but some time this week I'll update this page with photos of my machine and make sure all the files are up to date, then I'll create a parts list
comments.author: MarkPate

comments.text: sorry, the other images weren't loading for me.. the images look good. How much for a full kit with everything including the steel and all hardware, electronics, mechanicals...
comments.author: MarkButt

comments.text: Hey dude, great design.. looks very nice. I'm keen to purchase a kit off you, have you got any photos of the unit in use? I'm keen to build it with a steel frame and aluminium components, [email protected] ~thanks
comments.author: MarkButt

comments.text: Hi, as far as the framework goes - that aluminium framework is very, very overkill - and is like 3mm wall thickness aluminium box section. As for making other components out of aluminium - this is something I have done a bit of. I'll email you with the details of what parts would be made from 5mm aluminium etc.
comments.author: MarkButt

comments.text: Have you tested the system of using threaded and smooth rods for the Z axis that are not all on one plane? I've been thinking about that for a long time, but I'm not sure how stable it would be.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Hi,
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: I think he means that the Z threaded rods and smooth rods aren't all in the same plane, i.e. they don't all line up like they do in Mendel variants.
comments.author: Saminvent

comments.text: Technically you could have the smooth rods 45 degrees out so the spacing between them wider than the spacings of the threaded rods and have them further forward for more rigidity - although with linear bearings and 10mm rods this isn't really neccesary as they are still spaced apart.
comments.author: NewPerfection

comments.text: Hello,
comments.author: penny2009

comments.text: Hi Penny,
comments.author: penny2009

comments.text: are these all parts required ? great job btw. consider a lasercut ver.
comments.author: karandex

comments.text: I've designed it specifically to be quick for me or anyone else to produce - so part of that was to keep it stylish, simple, rigid, but at the same time use only high quality components more likely to be found on a fully fledged CNC machine. Which is why there are only a few printed parts needed - whilst they are some of the most important. The Bearings I use are From VXB and are some of the best 608 bearing available - from silicon nitride to chrome steel they all make the metal shielded bearings which need oil or grease (mine shouldn't be used with it) seem cheap and nasty - although unfortunately they aren't cheap and when you look at prusa kits you see how many are needed!!  Once I've got this machine working and hopefully got my money back from printing parts for a company I work for and by making more of these printers to sell, I'll probably be designing a laser cutter and so around that time I'll try to design a 3D printer for people with a laser cutter and/or a 3D printer - the idea being that if someone has either they can make the other!!   In my opinion anyone with a creative mind, a 3D printer and a laser cutter or mill is pretty unstoppable!!
comments.author: karandex

author: Andygp4711

description.text: For that one Z rod that has the wobble in it. If all your other Z rods are straight, install this floating bracket and keep the one wobbly rod from zigzaggling all your prints.  Thanks to twotimes for the bracket design; I thickened the outer portion, widened the screw holes, and reduced the vertex count to keep the hole printing ruly.

Print the wobble bracket, then remove the "zg" wooden piece from the Z stage on the rod that's wobbly. Install the wobble bracket under the Z stage. For extra wobble resistance, leave out two of the screws.  Then level out your Z stage platform again and you're done!

comments.text: It took me a few months to get my Makerbot #999 (ordered last May) finally assembled. But my Z Axis is not working at all. Tips say to print this, but I can't print anything because of the Z Axis grinding Spent about six hours today trying every tip I could find, but to no avail. So I HOPE this fix will really help. But I can't print. Will someone print 2 of these for me, and I will pay and have you send to me?
comments.author: Barry

comments.text: A solution suggested on the Makerbot blog is to leave one of your Z rods floating and unattached to the Z platform. That may reduce binding sufficiently to get a print out. I can't find the article right now but the idea is just to move the nut on your most bent Z-axis rod down so that it's not touching the Z platform, and so not making it bind.  This along with loosening the Z-axis belt a little may allow you to get a print off.
comments.author: Barry

comments.text: Hopefully using this I can make it stop skipping...
comments.author: feilen

comments.text: It did stop the skipping for me. I still have yet to find other wobbly rods, but I have noticed much better layer alignment and no more skipping.  :-D
comments.author: feilen

comments.text: really awesome.  the wobble on my makerbot was so bad that it'd wedge while traveling.  I installed one of these and problem solved!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Making it ruly is a good idea and I'm gruntled about it. I also think the design is wieldy, but when I tried to print it I got maculate results. I'll try alternative settings and redo. After all printing is still new hat to me.  ;)

comments.text: Read the description. "I thickened the outer portion, widened the screw holes, and reduced the vertex count to keep the hole printing ruly."

description.text:
A derivative to RyGuys Arduino Mega 2560 R3 Plate.
I removed the Bottom lid and merged both stl files into one with blender so I could print it in one piece.

UPDATE:
It seems that the first version fit on mine but on some other it did not fit (I tried it with 5 arduino boards and 3 of them fit on it but the other two didnt).
I added a version 2 where i changed some parameters like the size of the pins to 90% and added 1mm to the length of the holding area. I hope this fixes most problems but please check the sizes with your arduino board before printing. I used 10% infill and 0.4mm layer height. No support needed.
One edge bent up a little during printing but it was still ok.

comments.text: I made one, but I found the tolerances are too tight... The pins don't fit into the holes in the Mega, and the little lock pin wont fit in the slot... Great idea though.
comments.author: peterrash

comments.text: Hm I did not have that problem. It fit mine perfectly without sanding or anything. The lock pin is a very tight fit but that is as designed i guess. (I just took RyGuy's version and put the two files together).
comments.author: peterrash

comments.text: I haven't yet gotten around to upgrading from 0.8.4, so maybe I'll try that and reprint sometime. Great design, I just need to do more tweaking, I guess...
comments.author: bifi5590

comments.text: I rechecked the size with an arduino board of a friend. His board has 1mm more length and his usb and power jack are a little closer together.
comments.author: peterrash

comments.text: Looks good!  I need a bigger print bed...
comments.author: RyGuy

For a long time now, I've wanted to make a DIY pop machine. Now that I have access to cheap and rapid prototyping, it's time to revisit that project, and see if I can print a coin mech and a mechanism to dispense cans of soda, and wire all that up with an arduino and put it inside a wooden box. Toward that end, here's my first pass at a printable coin mech, based on this video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=85C4eh0mEJg If you want to hack with me, the repo is here:
https://github.com/iworkinpixels/Printable-Coin-Mech TODO:
1: Coin return. The cradles need to be on a hinge, and a coin return lever needs to open up the coin mech when pushed. This is especially important because if the mech rejects a slug, it will usually do so by getting stuck in the mech. We need a way for the next user to clear the mech, or this is a clear DoS attack vector. :) 2: Failsafe. If the machine is off, a lever which is normally held out of the way by an electromagnet should be released and push the coin mech open. 3: Switches. At the back of each coin chute should be a mounting point for a switch. 4: Storage. Each denomination of coin should fall into its own coin tube. 5: Rejection of objects larger than a quarter. At the very top of the mech, discs which are larger than a quarter should be automatically rejected. This may just be handled by making the coin slot to the outside of the machine just big enough to take a quarter. 6: Escrow. Not necessary, but it'd be nice if the coins that you have placed in the machine should be held in escrow until you dispense a soda, and returned to you if you press the coin return button. UPDATE 9/16/12: IT VERKS!!! I just got my first test rig printed, and (when I use pretend force instead of actual counterweights) it works! Now all I need to do is add some real counterweights and some switches and we should be in business!

1: Print one coin mech top, one coin mech bottom, and one set of coin mech cradles.
2: The cradles must be ordered in size from the biggest at the top of the mech to the smallest at the bottom, such that quarters catch at the top, nickels next, then pennies, then dimes.
3: Line up each hole and place a rod through the mech bottom, cradle and mech top. It will need to be just small enough that the cradle can spin freely.  Hold it in place by whatever means necessary; this is just a test rig!  Washers will probably be necessary.
4: The cradles need to have a small counterweight glued to the bottom of them, so that they will return to their starting position after the coin has fallen out of the cradle into the coin chute.

comments.text: The few coin mechanisms I've fiddled with all used the regular change instead of a physical escrow. Â (incoming tops off change reserves before dropping in the box) Â You're already counting the incoming, why add mechanical complexity?
comments.author: tyroney

comments.text: Speaking as someone who once worked with lots of coin mechs, you are entirely on the right track and this is awesome.Â  The cheap mass-produced coin mechs I used were finicky as hell and needed replacing often.

description.text:
UPDATE 2/11/2013 Case as seen in Develop3D Magazine! The STL's have been uploaded to the page again. Please do not resell them without my permission. This is an updated version of "Raspberry Pi Case" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24721 that I designed back in June. This new version fixes:
  • RCA Port misalignment
  • Headphone port misalignment
  • Walls not thick enough for .40 layer thicknesses
    • Additions:
  • Thicker
  • Open top for hacking
  • Vesa mount bottom

If you have a 200mm x 200mm you can print "RasPi Case2 Open Top and Bottom.stl" or "RasPi Case2 Top and Bottom.stl" If you have a smaller print surface than you will need to print the lid and the bottom separately. Lids:
  • RasPi Case2 Top.stl
  • RasPi Case2 Top Open.stl
  • RasPi Case2 Top Vented.stl
    • Bottoms:
  • RasPi Case2 Bottom Final.stl
  • RasPi Case2 Bottom Vesa.stl
    • You can also download RasPi_Case.zip and get all of the individual pieces in one download. Fit the 2 halves together and your done! The layers of the print should act like snap fittings and the case should snap closed! I print these with a .5 nozzle at .20 or .40 layer height, 2 shells/perimeters and .10 infill. Happy Printing!

This thing has moved to Youmagine: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/desktop-network-socket This is a network socket that you can put on a shelf or desk. It means you don't need to fiddle about behind or under furniture looking for the wall or floor socket. Instead, you can put the socket wherever you want it and just plug in a patch cable and away you go! I got the idea from some hotels which have a similar sort of thing on the desk in the room. Someone said to me "just use a bit of velcro" - yeah, you could, but where's the fun in that?

To make this part, you need a couple of extras. These are:
  • A "back to back" network coupler. This little gadget has a network socket on both sides and can be used to extend network cables. I got mine from Amazon for ÃÂ£0.33 UKP: http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B000MQM2FS/ref=oh_details_o02_s00_i00
  • Two counter-sink "number 2" screws. These are super-small screws, which you might be able to steal from various toys and other products if you're throwing things away. I got mine from here: http://www.modelfixings.co.uk (again, very cheap)
  • Optionally, a load of old screws, fishing weights, ball bearings or other weights (just to give the socket some weight on the desk).
    • Print the plate however you want (I did this with 0.2mm layers), but I'd recommend printing the dome in high quality (0.1mm layers). You don't need much in-fill for either part (15% seems to be enough). The dome has two hollow compartments on either side, and a rectangular slot into which you can put the network coupler (you can put a patch cable in the back now, or after you've assembled everything). Fill the two side compartments with weights, and possibly apply a bit of glue so that they don't rattle around. Then fit the plate over the top (it should gently click into place as it has four catches around the sides), then screw in the two screws. Plug in a patch cable if you didn't do so already and place the socket on your desk - easy!

Enclosure for a 12V Motor Controller. Can be resized with changes to the Openscad code.

An enclosure was needed for a standard 12V motor controller to add to our solar powered automated garden watering system. The controller seems to be readily available on ebay e.g. item 280913522973.
The Openscad code from Scanners Sparkfun enclosure was modified to change parameters for the size and add a lid. The external lugs were also re-orientated to avoid being overshadowed by the potentiometer control knob: The pictures shows an earlier version with the lugs in the wrong orientation.
Some self-amalgamating tape was used as a seal around the potentiometer control opening to reduce the ingress of water. The wiring openings were enlarged afterwards with a diamond file to allow for larger than expected diameter wiring.
Seperate STL files for the box and lid are given as they may be too big to fit on a makerbot build platform in one go.

comments.text: Sweet! I am happiest when something I do is helpful to someone else.

This is another m3-nut thumb-wheel that goes on those extra long m3-screws to fix the bed for levelling. this here has a little "dome", which makes it easier to rotate if several are used stacked upon each other, also you can easy see on which side the nut is!
Standard M3-nut fits nicely inside and is flush with the surface.
2 should be used per each of the 3 fixing points: 1 above and 1 below the bottom-plate OPPOSING each other (like on the photo) to clamp everything in place - this forms a "sandwich" with a stable plate in the middle, the abs and finally the metal nut. 2 springs in the front make levelling easier (third in the middle back is fixed/does not need a spring). That means there have to be printed out 6 in total, for 3-point bed-leveling (as seen in photo). Partly inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13778 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:346812

Recommended:
Print in ABS, solid or dense infill, 0.1 resolution

Bracket to mount the Printrbot auto-level induction probe to the wooden 2013 Simple printer (with a metal bed, of course). The photo is a very similar earlier version I printed. Based on the nice design contributed by dreadpirate15 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:302435). His bracket was not long enough to allow the probe to reach the bed so I lengthened it and made some other tweaks as well. This is my first contribution so please let me know if I didn't do something right. Hope you find it useful.

On my Simple XL, I had to change the configuration.h file to increase the calibration point from the right side since the firmware was trying to drive past the X max limit. I changed it from 10 mm to 30 mm as such: #define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION X_MAX_LENGTH-30  
For those who don't want to learn how to rebuild the firmware, you can shave 18 mm or so off the X max with the M211 command; e.g., from M211 X183 to M211 X165 (Note that my XL only goes to 183, not 185 mm.) This will prevent the calibration problem, but will also reduce your max print size.

title: (moved) improved camera slider V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
THIS DESIGN HAS BEEN MOVED TO YOUMAGINE:
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/camera-slider Reasons:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.de/2014/01/leaving-thingiverse.html I tried to improve on the camera slider by Matt Roberts by making the sides more versatile. You can mount the sider on a tripod now and mount equipment to it. All holes for bolts and rods are tapered for easy assembly.
All corners that a human hand can touch are rounded. V2:
I added M5 holes at a 45ÃÂ° angle into the feet, so you can insert threaded rods or bolts to dynamically add longer feet when needed.

Don't forget to mirror one side before printing. Mount a 40x10mm L bracket to help stabilise the slider.
Use 3mm grub screws to secure the 8mm rods.
Use 4x M5 bolts to mount the L bracket to the sides. Drill a center 1/4" hole into it and cut a UNC gear.
Also cut 1/4" gears into the center holes at top and bottom of both sides. Now you can mount your slider on one (center) or two (sides) tripods.
You can also mount a lamp, microphone or display to the top of a side.

This thing has moved to Youmagine: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/ultimaker-bowden-pop-stop This little gadget is for the Ultimaker v1 Hot End and does these things for you:
  • Is a printable solution to bowden slipping/popping problems
  • Solves the filament plugging in the hot end problem
  • Reduces the stress on any clamping solution (so the standard white clip is sufficient, if desired)
  • Makes the whole linkage of bowden, filament, brass and PEEK more tolerant to minor problems and easier to adjust and service
    • The Pop-Stop forms a solid barrier that fits inside the wooden head block. A short length of tube provides a filament path from the Pop-Stop to the brass nozzle (inside the PEEK part). The Pop-Stop prevents the tube from separating from the brass, and through the four long screws, it allows some pressure adjustment so that you can be assured a good fit between tube and brass without ever getting leakage that causes the traditional tube plugging/slipping/popping problems. The main length of Bowden (from the extruder) is then attached to the head and the Pop-Stop either by use of the standard white clamp and blue clip, or by an "Owen Clamp" (which is printable). It's possible to use e-clips or any other type of clamping solution - the good news is that most of the back-pressure force is absorbed by the Pop-Stop, so the clamp doesn't have to do very much work. Even if the clamp isn't very good and lets the tube slip a little during a long print, you won't get a plug and your print won't fail.

I printed this part in 0.2mm layers (ie. "standard" quality). High quality may work better if you can do it. It doesn't take long to print, so you won't have to wait long for it. I tend to use the "Joris" feature in Cura, but it's probably be fine without it (and probably fine in other slicing software). You need to clamp the bowden to the head. I personally use an "Owen Clamp" (found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11864 ), but you can use the standard white clamp and blue horseshoe clip (see notes below though), or any other clamping solution you happen to have. Once it'a all printed:
  • Heat up the hot end and remove the filament
  • Let it all cool down
  • Dismantle the hot end by removing the four long screws
  • Remove the bottom wooden plate (the one above where the aluminium plate goes
  • Remove the white clamp completely from the wooden plate
  • Insert the Pop-Stop into the wooden block (above where the nozzle usually is) - it only goes in one way around!
  • Replace the wooden plate onto the bottom of the block - it should push all the way back onto the wooden block
  • Cut 22mm off the end of your Bowden tube (try to cut the end off to be as perpendicular as possible). If you cut 23mm, that's probably okay, but don't cut less than 22!!
  • Push the short piece of tube into the hole in the wooden plate and make sure it does all the way up
  • Re-assemble the hot end (put the aluminium plate back on). The short tube should locate into the PEEK as normal, and then push up against the brass inside. When fully assembled, the aluminium plate will not quite push up against the wooden plate (there should be a 0.5mm gap) - this allows you to tighten the tube against the brass by tightening the long screws. I found finger tight + a quarter turn seemed to work best (don't over-tighten as you'll deform the tube)
  • If using the Owen clamp, thread the gnurled cap and tightening cone onto the long length bowden
  • If using the white clamp, insert it into the top of the wooden head (see notes below)
  • Push the bowden tube into the hole in the top of the wooden block and tighten the clamp. You need a close fit between tube and Pop-Stop, but do not need the super-strong, high pressure fit that you used to need against the brass!
  • Re-thread your filament (see notes below)
  • Get printing!
    • Clamps
    I'm using the Owen Clamp, because I already have one and I found the white clamp didn't quite fit in the top of my wooden block. It fits in the hole, but is too close to the walls of the block to function correctly. If your block is the same, then you can solve the problem by cutting a small amount off the wooden walls of the block. Caveat maker ;-) It's also possible to use any other clamping solution you happen to have. "Eclips" seem to be fairly common, and will work (same caveats as the white clip above though). Filament Threading
    I found the first time to be quite a challenge! I've found that not tightening the clamp makes it easier to push the filament through (tighten the clamp once it's threaded though!). You may also find that trimming the tip of the filament into a point helps quite a bit. Once you've done it once (and tightened your clamp) then it's easy after that. So what's all this done?
  • You now have an absolutely rock-solid connection between tube and brass. No plugs!
  • The clamp you've used only needs to overcome the force of the extruder (and doesn't have to overcome the force required to keep the tube agaist the brass). This means you don't need a very strong clamp (or don't need to tighten it much)
  • If the tube slips by a millimeter or two, it may affect extruding quality, but you won't "pop" the tube, you won't get a plug and your print won't fail!!
    • Things left to do in the Pop-Stop
  • Make filament threading a little easier
  • Try to improve the printing quality of the bowden tube hole in the bottom of the part - it needs a bit of cleaning up with a craft knife at the moment due to the design of the part and the tiny amounts of space available inside the wooden block
  • Make an "upper" section for the Pop-Stop so that the tube meets the Pop-Stop on the top of the wooden block (which means the part lengthens the Bowden by about 50mm, and works very well with Owen Clamps and Swagelock tubes.

This box allows you to plug in a Model 500 GE Telephone with a proprietary Bell System connector. Details on how it was created are available on the Workshop 88 blog: http://blog.workshop88.com/new-well-old-workshop-phone/

The 'plugbox' STL file allows you to print the top part of the box. The 'plugbox_cover' STL file allows you to print the bottom cover. The box is designed to allow you to put a square of perfboard inside. If you need to change any of the details, the project is also available via GitHub: https://github.com/rlankenau/model-500-phone-adapter

This is designed to fit with my water-cooling setup (coming soon)
ignore nozzle stl that is just for thingivers...

build very similar to v1 with a few changes:
-Nozzle-
4mm hole for liner
Use end mill to create a better seat for the liner end. I like this better than trying to file a taper on the teflon... it also keeps the liner from potentially squeezing at the hot end and creating a blockage
-Barrel-
Much easier now there is no need for an internal wall, the tubing connector puts pressure on the liner. Drilling a long 4mm hole through the SS is difficult. Drill bit wander is ok on the other side so long as it isn't extreme.
-Parts-
--McMasterCarr--
  • 3/8-24 Brass rod (98813A031 $13.04 for 24")
  • 3/8-24 Stainless Steel threaded rod (93250A150 $16.19 for 36")
  • Thick brass 3/8-24 nuts (92676A455 $5.20 for 10)
  • Thin brass 3/8-24 nuts (92174A663 $8.71 per 25)
  • 3/8" x 3/4" Aluminum bar stock (89215K483 $37.73 for 36")
  • 4mmOD, 2mmID Teflon tubing (5557K32 $1.53/ft)
  • 4mm tube to M5 tube fitting (7880T368 $1.65 each)
  • 40W 12V ceramic heater (yes you can use a resistor if you really want) buy on ebay or from 3d printer supplier
  • axial thermister or thermocouple
    Tools:
  • Metal Lathe
  • Center

  • 77 drill bit (or whatever orifice size you want)

  • 4mm cobalt (or carbide) drill bit (29355A64 $3.14 each) get a few
  • 4mm sharp tipped drill bit (for brass) (27465A413 $4.56)
  • 5/16" drill bit
  • 4mm 2 flute end mill (4 flutes is fine) for brass (29605A22 $14.18)
  • M5x0.8 tap (for pneumatic fittings) (26475A38 $8.68)
  • 3/8-24 tap (for aluminum)
  • drill bit for thermister/thermocouple
    Machining Steps
    -Nozzle-
    1. Face one end of bar
    2. Create a center divot
    3. Drill orifice being VERY careful. Go in ~ 2mm, using small steps
    4. Use compound cross feed to taper tip; I like 45 degrees, smooth is best. Make sure there is no divit left
    5. Part off the tip leaving some extra length
    6. Face new end
    7. Create a new center divit
    8. Measure length of nozzle and set tailstock at zero with sharp tip flush with end of nozzle
    9. Drill in to about 1.5mm less than the length of the nozzle
    10. Use a flat end mill to create an internal edge leaving the center taper
    11. File flats at the nozzle end and make sure the nozzle is still clear
      -Barrel-
    12. Do a rough cut from stock material
    13. Face one end and create a divit with a center (alignment critical)
    14. Drill all the way through with the 4mm drill bit. Take your time and use lots of cutting fluid. If the drill bit wobbles at the start it is off-center... try again.
    15. Mark the side that started from and flip the part around and face the other end
    16. Drill in 5-10mm with the 4.2mm drill bit
    17. Tap M5-0.8 being careful with the bit
    18. Finally cut the thermal break gap (not sure if necessary but doesn't hurt) with a cut-off tool... don't go too far
      -Teflon Liner-
    19. Cut the liner tubing a little extra long
    20. Put the Nozzle and Barrel together with the liner inside
    21. Screw in the push-fit connector into the barrel
    22. This should push the nozzle and barrel apart so cut the liner by a little less than the amount of liner that is showing
    23. When put back together the tightened push-fit connector should create a small gap between the nozzle and barrel
    24. Chamfer the end of the liner that is opposite the nozzle to help filament feed

A Slide on / off nema 17 box with a screw hole for long screws. This is for lowering your Z end stop for head attachments that go below the current Z end stop. The longer screw reaches the switch from higher up. It slides on and off easily at any time.

Fuse mounting panel used to mount fuse holders.

I did this to my machine after blowing my poly fuses using 24v.  
Know your machine. Know your capability. Proceed at your own risk.  
I removed the blown fuses from the RAMPS board and replaced them with a jumper (See Jumper pic). The fuses are wired in between the power supply and the RAMPS board. I put a 10A fuse in line with the 11A input to RAMPS. I put a 5A fuse in line with the 5A input to RAMPS. The printer powered right up and has been running happily for many prints.  
After designing the panel to a close tolerance, I had to open the holes slightly after printing. I did have to print with support.

remixed_from.title: Timing Belt X GT2, Printrbot Simple V2

title: Printrbot Simple (Incl. GT2) X Axis Easy Bed Upgrade (Printable on stock Simple)

description.text:
This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:190238 What did I do? I made it printable on the stock 100mm x 100mm x 100mm bed of the Simple. You will need some extra hardware. You need: 6x M3 Hex Nut
6x M3 7-10mm screws
4x 4" Zip Ties
Super Glue (Optional) Please note: I have no tried this yet! My supplies will be in in a few days. I will update to confirm that the print works in a few days. There are small notches in the main piece that line up with the end pieces, these are "keyed" so you can't mess them up. It's pretty obvious how it goes together, but it also makes it so you don't need glue (Though I would recommend it) I am currently finishing the new version with middle supports. It will be up soon in addition to the standard one. You may choose whichever you like. Michaeli, the original designer, recommended I add extra supports. To attach the GT2 belts supports, just align the notches (these are keyed just like the other pieces), place zip ties through the holes, add a dab of super glue, and tighten everything. Download all the files from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:194686, but do not print the supports, only print the motor mount plate, 2 bearing caps, and 2 tension blocks. Follow installation instructions from that. The assembly is the same once you have my parts attached. The measurements from Jon's GT2 ends should match mine, though they're nicer looking! Don't forget this is still a WIP until I can check everything! Thanks!

A model of a classic roadster, loosely based upon the Snowberger-Offy 1949 Indy 500 race car.  This roadster makes a great toy or model, with working wheels and real rack-and-pinion steering!  Parts are designed to be printable, with easy snap-together assembly (and a little super glue).  
STL files of the individual parts are included in the downloads, as well as the source wings3d file.  An additional wings3d file shows all the parts as assembled.  You have the source:  Take this model and improve it!

This roadster is an extension of the body shape I designed as a shell for a pinewood derby racer (Thing 282791). Lifted from the restrictions of the derby, I was able to make the wheels properly proportioned and positioned to the body. The wood block chassis got replaced by a plastic chassis accomodating a steering column and real rack-and-pinion steering for the front wheels. Details like exhaust pipes and a front grille that can be printed in a separate color complete the model. Print the body top and bottom and hubcaps in your favorite race car color. Print the driver in white or natural, and paint the details. Print the wheels, seat, grille, and steering wheel and column in black. The remainder of the parts look good in black, gray, or silver. The fine-detail parts are the pinion gear, steering wheel, rack, axles, hinges, grille, and exhaust pipes. These should be printed in as fine detail as you can manage (I printed them with 0.1mm layer heights). Most parts can print without support material, but the notable exceptions are the body top, the exhaust pipes, the driver, and the hinges. Most pieces should print reliably without a raft. Be careful with the hinges, however, as they probably require a raft to prevent them from detaching from the base during printing. But the raft will likely stick to the parts, giving the pins a larger effective diameter. Sand down as necessary to fit, and drill out holes to make sure they're clean. All holes are in one of two sizes, the smaller of which matches a 1/8" drill bit, and the larger of which matches an 11/64" drill bit. To get good hinges, rack, and pinion gear, you will need a good printer and a good slicer! Assemble the front and rear axle halves, the steering column, and hinges with super glue. All of these pieces will be held in place, so that the glue is just a precaution. Attach wheels to the axles (should work with a press-fit). For extra strength, two collars (rings) are included with the STL file for the steering column, and can be slid down the steering column to better secure the two pieces. Assemble all the pieces together as shown in the exploded diagram.
Start with the axles, hinges and wheels. Push the wheels onto the axles. Then push the front axles into the hinges (see the exploded diagram for reference---make sure the orientation of the hinges is correct!). Place the rack, hinges, and wheel assemblies on the chassis, and secure the body bottom over the chassis to hold all the wheels in place. The back wheels should rotate freely, and the front wheels should turn together. Snap the seat into the body top, and run the steering column through the hole. Do not attach the steering wheel until the end.
Holding the body top and bottom close together, insert the end of the steering column into the hole at the front of the chassis, then slide the body top into place and press-fit it onto the body bottom. Push the steering wheel onto the steering column. Leave the exhaust pipes and grille for last; these will need to be glued on. The driver can be put in and taken out of the completed vehicle.

comments.text: Which part appears to be messed up?  The main body (top part)?  It is probably non-manifold in spite of my efforts to keep it manifold, which means that what you see could be very dependent on what tool you use to view it.  I sliced and printed it in Simplify3D, which didn't flag any issues with it.

comments.text: The entire back right corner is completely messed up. I don't know if it is the Cad I use to edit things I download or the print itself. If you could I would appreciate it if you could look into this problem. If it helps I use tinkercad.com to edit items.

comments.author: jrscomputer2

comments.text: I guess you can try running through meshlab.  I checked with the slicer tool I use, which is Simplify3D, and it claims that the upper body model is properly manifold, and passes all checks.  I double-checked that the file posted on Thingiverse is the same one that I have on my computer.  So I'm not sure what causes your slicer to improperly fill in the holes.
comments.author: jrscomputer2

comments.text: Oops. I looked at the chassis and found that it failed a manifold check, and then fixed it up without looking closer at it, and then copied it on top of the body bottom STL file. I guess that teaches me not to do a rush job like that! Anyway, I went back and looked at the body bottom model, and saw why it's causing the slicer so much trouble. Back when I made that design, I had not yet figured out how to use the "weld" feature in Wings3D. So a few of the pieces were not quite right. . . and fail manifold checks. I have now moved the corrected chassis to the right file name, and uploaded the corrected body bottom file. Let me know if your slicer complains about any other parts.
comments.author: TimEdwards

comments.text: Well the slicer is happy! Printing now. looking good. Thanks once again.
comments.author: TimEdwards

comments.text: Ok! It is reassuring to know at least in this respect I am not as crazy as I was beginning to think I was.  hehehe   Pete, my husband says that is debatable, by the way. Thanks again, Tim

comments.text: I just switched out the "roadster_model_body_bottom.stl" file with a new one.  The Wings3D program didn't get the left-to-right mirroring quite right;  maybe the model was not quite flat at the mirror point.  I removed the automatic mirroring, copied one side to the other, and merged them together.  The new STL passes all manifold checks, so it ought to slice properly.  In theory.

This is an adapter cup used to install an upgraded speaker into your Taranis Tx. It's designed to pull out the stock one and install a larger, clearer 36mm speaker obtained from the east bay and far east :-)
Check Out item # 310952191496
It should not require support turned on to print.
I used hot glue to tack the adapter into the Tx and then the speaker into the adapter.
(Ok, so here's the crazy thing, you can feel the air movement from the low range this speaker puts out. It sounds great and cost next to nothing to upgrade.)
When you install be aware of the two centering posts (left and right) and their height. This adapter is designed to avoid interference with them and your new speaker so you will not need to modify your radio by clipping them. Just make sure that when you install the adapter it is level. I used a piece of scrap foam to insure no interference. You can us a scrap piece of plastic or card, ...

Printable earring hooks.
This is one of the most surprising thing I ever printed. I was sure it was going to be a failure but turns out they work very well! They are surprisingly durable.

I print them in PLA. So far no one had any bad reaction to them.
Given what PLA is made of I think its safer than ABS. I did not use any special settings to print them, they are so thin that they come out full no matter what you do. I have a 0.35mm nozzle. If the little rings are not split, cut them and use two of them to attach a hook to your earring. This way even if the split lines up with the frame of the hook it doesn't slip out, its called redundancy :P Now you have the hooks! Time to create more Printable earrings everyone!

This is a radius gauge, for figuring out the radius of an object.  Works for inside and outside curves.  Guages for radii of 20 to 69 mm, in 1 mm increments.

There are several plates, grouped by radius. Plate30.stl contains guages for 30 to 39mm, etc. Print out the plate(s) that you want. After that, stack the gauges from that plate and measure the thickness. Then choose the bracket that matches that thickness and print it. So use bracket19_5.stl if the thickness of those 10 gauges is 19.5 mm. Then attach it all using a M3 x 25mm flathead screw, similar to this one http://amzn.com/B000FN3NS8. The reason for the multiple bracket versions is because the actual thickness of each gauge depends on how you leveled your build platform-- and thus how much the first layer or two got smashed down. The variation won't be huge, but multiply that by the 10 gauges per bracket and it can add up. I highly recommend using a dark, opaque filament. Black, blue, etc would be good. Natural or anything translucent would be bad. The reason for this is you want to see the gap between the gauge and the object you are measuring and it's hard to see the gap unless it blocks the light fairly well. I printed these at 0.2 mm layer height, 20% infill, and 2 extra shells (3 total).

description.text:
Inspired by whowhatwhere\'s cookie cutters, I decided to take a stab at making a more generalizable cookie cutter pattern.
This OpenSCAD script has parameters for the standard dimensions, but it also has a \"primitive\" module which you can replace with any scalable flat shape.  It creates a wall in 3 thicknesses -- a thick lip at the very bottom, a sturdy wall for most of the height, and then a single-filament-width tip at the very top.

• Open Cookie in OpenSCAD
  • Set your desired diameter.
  • Replace the guts of the \"primitive\" module with whatever flat shape you want. I took Catarina Mona\'s shapes library and made octagon, hexagon, and cross shaped patterns. Obviously if you wanted to do something more fancy, you might want to use OpenSCAD\'s DXF extrusion.
  • Design -> Compile and Render (F6)
  • Design -> Export as STL
  • Skeinforge and pay close attention to the layer thicknesses in skeinview. Generally the lip should have a little fill, the middle should be double-pathed and the tip should be ~2 layers of single path. You may have to tune the layer width parameters in cookie.scad to get this perfect.
  • Print

I made it a while ago as a gift for E and to see if I could design and make something with my Makerbot Cupcake. I figured I'd clean it up a bit (still some warnings from skeinforge) and share it.
I might be able to make a more faithful replica now that I have more experience.

You probably should abort your first print after the first 10 layers or so and use the disk to check that it fits your espresso machine. If not, scale accordingly and reprint.
Additionally, you probably want this to be stronger than a usual print, maybe a few extra shells. The infill doesn't have to be crazy to work, though.
No need for support material.

description.text: pendant

With my FlashForge Creator, I didn't have any success with the built-in extruder alignment pattern--the settings that resulted didn't improve my alignment.
So I evolved a test object that makes it fairly easy to measure the errors with calipers. I print in MakerWare to get the wipe wall, but set the offsets using ReplicatorG (because MakerWare can't talk to machine parameters for a FlashForge Creator running SailFish--some kind of map error).
I found it helpful to plot my errors vs settings on graph paper, eliminated a lot of dumb mistakes due to forgetting which sign convention I was using for the errors.
The .scad file has comments that explain the use in some detail.
it is my pendent

remixed_from.title: Shell approximation of solid of revolution I

title: Shell approximation of solid of revolution II
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The model pictured on the left is the solid obtained by revolving the region between the graph of y=(x-1)(x-3)^2 and the x-axis on [1,3] around the y-axis. The model in the back is an approximation of that solid using 8 shells, and the model on the right is an approximation with 16 shells. This particular volume is the same one computed with a definite integral at https://www.khanacademy.org/math/integral-calculus/solid_revolution_topic/shell-method/v/shell-method-for-rotating-around-vertical-line, in case you feel like doing some calculus. For more information about the math behind approximating volumes with shells, see the link below. MakerHome, Day 238:
http://makerhome.blogspot.com/2014/04/day-238-shellmaker-2.html =====

This design and all associated pictures and files are licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial Share Alike license. If you want to use designs, images, or files outside of the terms of this license, please email [email protected].

author: Ajakeski

description.text: If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays The battle has raged on for centuries. How will it end, on the field of strategy or in the grapple of combat? Only you can decide. Finally the original Chessbot Hero (Formerly Action #Chess) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25084 has a worthy opponent. This new robot assembles in a different and unique way to the original. Edit this thing on Tinkercad: https://tinkercad.com/things/iZLcB97CLRN-action-chess-opponent Also available on Etsy if you can't print one: https://www.etsy.com/listing/109657227/

Be sure your filament diameter works by printing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27436 until they mate well. I find my filament diameter needs to be up to one or two tenths of a milimeter more than what I actually measure to get a good mate.
  • Form the body by sliding the tabs on the king and queen into the other and sliding.
  • From the head by taking the two "F" pawns and mating them base-to-base.
  • Slide the 4 "A" pawns into the body to form shoulders and legs.
  • Slide the head into the slot at the base of the king.
  • Join the "B" pawns to the knights base-to-base.
  • Join the rooks to the legs to form feet.
  • Join the Bishops to the shoulders and the knight/pawn arms to the bishops.
  • Pose and play.

title: Universal Camera mount for web camera

description.text: This is a universal camera mount for a web camera that you can print out and fasten to your 3D printer for recording video or live feeds.  I couldn't find a mount that I liked so I made this.  You bolt it together with 1 #8-32 1", 2 #8-32 1.25" and 1 #8-32 .75".  This mount allows you to quickly move the camera out of the way of a enclosure door when opening the door.  It has a 3 part pivot and you can print out as many brackets as you want.  They measure 3 inches.  Try out and let me know how you like it.
Printed in ABS 25% fill on all parts.

author: Briggsred

title: Vertical carriage for Rostock with Jonas KÃ¼hling's LM8UU holder

description.text:
I liked the LM8UU holders for my prusa mendel using this X-Carriage:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23897 I decided to make one for the Rostock (build in progress). This is listed under work in progress until the Rostock is fully built. UPDATE 10-07-2012:
My Rostock is "plotting" now.
I discovered that my LM8UUs were sloppy on my drill rod so I doubled them up with this:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32000

What I used in Slic3r:
0.35 nozzle.
0.20 layer height with 0.25 for the first layer.
45 deg fill at 40 percent fill using line method.
No brim and no support material. This was done in 3mm ABS on my Prusa Mendel v2. Brims and support material is built into the model to prevent curling and support the brackets for the m3x20 and nut. To use the scad file, you will need the files from the github:
https://github.com/jcrocholl/rostock
and the scad from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16158 There are parameters to change the first layer height if it does not slice correctly. The STL is using 0.25 for the first layer. The LM8UU bearings should fit snugly in the holders without the bolts and should not require much torque to secure them well.

comments.text: Running a Mendel with a 0.5mm nozzle, no issues printing, told slicer to generate support.  Put them on my Rostock as it went 3D today  (i.e. fitted the parts to the wood, and the steel rods between :)    Just for giggles, I compared the originals to these and these are definitely more secure/stable.  Well done, O Creator :)  and thanks :)
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Note: for people that have 0.5mm nozzles, you will need to adjust the scad (extrude_width) otherwise support won't be generated in your sliced model.
comments.author: sgraber

comments.text: I'm using a 0.35mm nozzle and I also had to increase extrude_width before the support would print. (I used Skeinforge instead of Slic3r, so perhaps that made a difference)
comments.author: sgraber

title: Threaded Filament Dust Filter + Knurl = Replicator 1,2 & 2X

description.text:
The Threaded Filament Dust Filter (for dust and adding oil)
was made by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:153807
I saw someone added a knurl in a remix, At the time it didn't include the files but they do now.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:258598
Theirs has a knurl that makes the filter wider.
I need mine to fit in a smaller area, and it is not important enough for a dual color print.
So my knurl is recessed. In version 1
Version 1 didn't print as the knurl was too small. So I made a dual color printable wide knurl version just now. I did add a knurl to the male part too, so I added another few files for individual and dual set parts. Sorry these are BIG stl files.

No raft, no support
50% infill
3 shells
.27mm layers
102% scale on the larger female part for ABS
with active cooling airflow after the print has started the first layer.
220F extrude
110F hotbed For more, please see instructions and comments from:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:153807

author: activezombie

title: Yosemite's Glacier Point featuring the 4-Mile trail and the Ledge Trail

description.text: This is a 3d topo map of Yosemite's Glacier Point showing two of the trails which connect Glacier Point to the valley floor. The 4-mile trail is a steep and strenuous hike. The Ledge trail is an insane scramble over dangerous steep terrain, so dangerous that the trail was officially closed years ago following a number of fatalities. You can still climb it (people climb far sillier rocks in Yosemite) but don't say you weren't warned. This model may not be used as a navigation aid and the accuracy of the routes shown is not guaranteed. The model was made using Lidar data from http://opentopo.sdsc.edu/ which was collected to study rockfall. Keep that in mind if you are considering the Ledge route. Here is my video tutorial showing how to make 3d prints from Lidar https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t4-ICkvyJv0

author: samurai_gui

description.text:
Brought to you guys by the guys at https://www.3dprint-uk.co.uk There are many of you out there who spend an unhealthy amount of time looking at pointless but funny things on the internet. We however are working so hard to get things to you on time that we never have the time to do this. However over the Christmas break we were sent a gif on imgur, with the challenge of making a physical representation of the Internet of Stupid, and a lightbulb appeared above the combined heads of the 3DRPINTUK team and finally we were able to show the world an apt use for a 3D printed mechanism that we could all enjoy! and thus the boob poop machine was born! it's almost certainly one of the most important advances in 3D printing history. Out of respect for the creators, we'd ask you to keep the logo if possible, but if you have a friends name you'd rather put on it... haha.. we're totally ok with that! Please do not sell this elsewhere or use it for your own marketing though ;) Please also note that this has been made on an SLS machine and not tested on consumer FDM machines. Youtube Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pa14LbOT9r8
3DPRINTUK Site: https://www.3dprint-uk.co.uk/

description.text:
I purchased a couple of sets of "LED Throwies Pack" from Zazz (https://www.zazz.com.au/daily/thingy/6047) a while ago - primarily for the cheap CR2032 "button" batteries.
Everything arrived, but I found that the batteries were packed in a tape-type plastic and once I took one out I had batteries everywhere.
To keep the batteries separated (and make it easier to select "just one") I made this holder. It holds 40 (4x10) batteries. You can print 1 (open top) or 2 (for a full case).

Fan bracket for cooling the extruder stepper of a printrbot plus (2013)
fits 50mm fan.
No nuts needed only 4mm screws. 2 x 8-10 for the bracket and 1 -2 20mm for attaching the arm to the bracket and the whole assy to the bot

When attaching the arm to the bracket, use a 4mm drillbit through the arm screwholes, but not through the bracket, the screws will then move freely in the arm but thread the hole in the bracket so you dont need any nuts

description.text: This model illustrates an interesting planetary drive variation that produces a very low gear ratio. Click the video link to see it in action: http://youtu.be/P-Obt-9tZVo

The video shows how it works and includes some construction tips. You'll probably want to make the Tube cutting tool as well: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30619 I started designing this in metric units, but was only able to find brass tubing in imperial sizes, so I simply used both measurement systems. If you live in a metric part of the world, you should be able to adapt to locally available materials by drilling out the bearing holes as necessary

comments.text: Interesting concept. But this means that the module of the second ring does not exactly match the sun module, does it? It guess it works fine with plastic gears, but it would not work as well with metal gears (ar at least with a lot of friction)... In fact, this is a mix between a standard planetary gears and harmonic drive ;o)
comments.author: fma

comments.text: Yes, strictly speaking, the planet gears should have a step in the middle, with a slightly different diameter where they intersect the driven ring, and the sun gear should only intersect the half that meshes with the stationary ring. In this model, the difference is well below the manufacturing tolerance of the gears.
Very nice :)
